text:
Very kind introduction. It's right. I did switch three years
into a six-year PhD.

So if anyone ever wants
to make an enormous leap, I have in the past
served as a resource, and I'm happy to again.

So but today, at least for the
formal part of our interaction, I'm here to talk about systems
for helping people form

ideas about what they want to
do and better understanding of the world and how
they want to act on it and how they communicate
that to others,

especially if that other
is a computer, rather than another human being. So I also want to
just acknowledge

the generous funding of
course Harvard and the Harvard Radcliffe Institute which
supported me over the last year

and of course, the NSF for
which much of this work would not have happened. So let's-- I think it's so
beautiful that Michael mentioned

that I started in HCI thinking
about large classrooms because I actually, in reflecting on
what I wanted to share with you

today, I came all the way back
to that origin story of why was

I doing human
computer interaction. I was a teaching fellow in a
massive undergraduate computer

architecture class where
people were producing pages and pages of esoteric code
that was only in that class,

that professor had invented the
language that was unreadable 30 years ago, we
were still using it. And so, I as a TF would
go from student to student

and just be like, there's
not the right division of labor here. I can't look at these pages of
code and know what's going on.

The computer could
look at it, right? If only the computer
could help me

have a better awareness of
all the different design choices that are being
populated by all these students

such that I could have
the kind of conversations that only I as a TF, as a
human can have with them.

So for example, we
found that students were constructing Turing machines.

Most TFs had taken
the class before they had made their Turing
machine and that was the way you made it
to satisfy the assignment.

And so when they
met a student who was making the Turing
machine some other way, they'd say, what are you doing?

That's wrong. Start over. Right? When in reality, there were
multiple Turing machines that met the spec.

And by analyzing the
space of solutions, we were able to
tell the TF, we were able to better inform how
they would act in the world.

And so this notion of helping
people act better in the world

and understand what
they want to do, what conversations
they want to have, it comes up again when I'm
talking with my collaborators

in the medical world. Right? I have a collaborator who's
in chronic pain management.

And he says, yes, there's
one of 20 different drugs I could prescribe.

But a huge part of it is the
relationship with the patient and me helping them understand
that given their sensitivities

to various prior drugs'
side effects, that-- we're having a
conversation, he's

almost selling in a good way,
helping them consolidate a plan to address their pain with
the chosen medication.

And computers can help. That doctor maybe-- think
about the back-- instead of doing mental
back of the envelope

calculations of like
quick pattern matching, oh yeah, this drug worked for
this similar person last time, we can help them.

So this is the kind of problem
that I find really exciting. One last connection
here is when we're

thinking about communicating
to the computer or thinking about how
the computer is playing

this role, like I like
this particular stock photo because it reminds me that
sometimes in our user studies,

we found that, say
we're trying to-- we're asking the user to give
examples of what they want.

And the computer will
try to guess, something, a program that fulfills what
the user in this study wants.

And sometimes in
that interaction, the user will be
like, oh, I got it. I know the regular
expression that I want.

I can write it down
for you right now. But in our interface, because
we were so focused on supporting

them to get the
computer to guess it, that we never had an
interface affordance to allow them to
write in the answer.

Like we were so focused
on the communication to the computer as opposed to-- what really matters is that the
person walks away with the thing

they need. So I generally think of this
as AI-assisted task formulation

and or AI-assisted
task completion. So each of my projects,
sometimes, it's

just helping the user have
a better understanding of what they want to do. Sometimes, it's
helping-- they have

a notion of what
they want to do, and the AI is helping them
achieve it, sometimes it's both. And so I actually think
about this now more than ever

as a conversation. So you can go back
to on language by Herbert Clark from a
book by a psychologist,

I think, emeritus
now here at Stanford. A classic on all
the minute steps

that make conversation
between humans work. And so I've been asking myself--

well, if you remove the human
and introduce some silicon, what parts of those
little things change?

What little interface
affordances are possible? Or what are additional
cognitive tasks

that if we're not aware
of them, we may design an interface that is subpar? So I am not going--
oh, sorry, yeah.

And by the way,
just as a caveat, I know there's some
approaches out there in computer science which try to
model the context, the opinions,

the values, the goals. All that I am just
assuming in all of my work that that is inaccessible and is
a fool's errand to try to guess.

So just not to say that
it's not valuable work, but that's not generally
what I'm trying to do.

So human AI communication. I am currently
accumulating from all

of these papers over the years. I'm trying to think about all
of these little pieces, all

the little details. So I'm going to step
you through the details that I've identified so
far from these papers.

They require
controlled user studies to fully falsifiable
hypotheses to test to tell you

that these are exactly right. But I'm going to
tell you about them in case they spur your thought
about what you might look into.

And then I'm going to go
into detail into our two most recent papers-- one
that was conditionally accepted on Friday.

And then I'll talk about for
the first time so bear with me. OK. So first thing that
I've noticed is--

just to go real fast, when
you're expressing your intent, sometimes, you realize
as you are expressing it,

that the intent is not quite
what you thought it was. Right? So there's intent
refinement opportunities

at the expression point. If you allow people to
provide multiple expressions

of they're-- like I think this
constraint is something I care about. But in parallel, also
say, actually there's

this other constraint,
maybe that's the one that I care about. Suddenly, if they are not
forced to commit to something,

it's much less
anxiety-provoking to say-- computer, try this
or-- so removing

the anxiety or the consequences
of giving a specification that ends up not being what you want.

Parallel program synthesis
in the assuage program. This was this was a
huge win to our users.

Supporting multiple
modalities, if possible, like annotating concrete
examples or allowing them

not just saying words
or that kind of thing.

Extracting and displaying a
diversity of examples from data if the data is
available or generating

a diversity of examples. So again, from psychology
literature, common ground, those examples can be that
grounding common ground that

reflect what you want and are
also observable to the computer unlike the values that
you hold in your mind

over your personal values. Also, like showing inferred
commands, if possible.

Just the simple difference
between talking to your Google Home Mini versus Siri
on your phone where

you can see the transcription
of what it thinks you said make a huge difference.

The system state, the same way
that you ask your Google Home Mini in your kitchen
to cancel the timer

and it does, but you didn't
realize it had two timers and it canceled the wrong one
because it was confidently

wrong because requesting
clarifications if the system is uncertain
is not foolproof because--

all of these issues-- again, these are
just observations that I've accumulated over
working on these projects

that I'm sharing
with you right now. The integration step,
I think that we often--

there's been a lot of work
including some of my own on creating writing
assistants like,

hey, ChatGPT or a large language
model could continue my sentence and maybe that will
serve as inspiration

for where I want to go. Many of you are probably
making use of predictive text in your Gmail.

There is non-trivial integration
costs that we can think about

that have come up, especially
when you're doing more creative tasks as opposed to dashing
off an email or we can--

there's a lot of cost in looking
over the results of execution. So this is really just the
good old gulf of evaluation.

Flash fill, the one of the first
program synthesis tools that was commercially available.

You could go into excel and
give a couple of examples, and it will synthesize
an Excel formula

that it thinks is what you
want and yet it gives you basically no support for
looking over thousands

and thousands of rows of data. So there's all these
kind of inner tasks

that are maybe subtle. But that if we
don't support them, we are batting below our
possible batting average

in terms of supporting
the quickness and accuracy and fewest number of round
trips to get to what we want

and have the computer
correctly understand it. Finally, with each one
of these interactions,

person is going to be
updating their mental model of the machine,
hopefully correctly, and updating their
mental model of the world

and any relevant data. So I think-- I put this out here
as a living document

as I accumulate and do systems. I think each one of these-- you can take them and
go to a new domain

and say, what are the
implications of this-- of supporting this cognitive
task in this new domain?

And if you do that,
please tell me about it. So I am going to talk about this
loop in the context of our most

recent paper, PaTAT, which is-- the pattern-based
thematic annotation tool.

This work is in collaboration
with Toby Li's lab. And led by Simret but also with
the help of Zhang, Xiaohang

and Yihao. And so this is conditionally
accepted under the title

Human-AI Collaborative
Qualitative Coding with Explainable
Interactive Rule Synthesis.

So the backstory-- because you
can read the paper eventually,

but you can't
necessarily get access to the backstory
behind the paper. The small backstory
behind this is that--

I mentioned flashfill. When I was a postdoc at Berkeley
and hired on a program synthesis

grant, I had to do-- I was required to do
one program synthesis project as an HCI person. I said, I don't know what
that is, but I will do it.

I highly recommend
putting yourself out there like that if you have the
opportunity because it

was the hammer I
didn't know I needed. Basically, Microsoft
had just come out

with this toolkit called
Prose, where it was like, hey, we have a set of grammars over,
say, patterns and strings or you

could give us a grammar. And we will-- if you
give us examples, we'll synthesize
a program to you in that grammar
that meets your spec

and given your ranking function
is hopefully what you want.

And of course, the
devil's in the details in terms of designing
that ranking function or designing an interface
that supports you,

recognizing the program you
want given an imperfect ranking function. So I've always wanted to have
interactive programs synthesis,

programs be
synthesized over text. But not just the
raw text, patterns

in raw text but patterns
over parts of speech. That seemed like a much
more powerful grammar
that they did not have. And so we did it. This-- sorry, this is like--

that's the high level-- I'm extraordinarily
excited that-- and the application
that we decided

to apply this to show its
utility is thematic analysis. So thematic analysis in terms
of a rich human-AI communication

problem is one where
it's iterative, where the user requires
deep engagement

on the part of the
user, and there are many different
valid outcomes,

because I mean,
obviously, we talk about inter-rater reliability. But if anyone's
familiar with that paper

about iterative reliability
being not always the most important thing,
it could even move you away

from interesting
observations that are less frequent because you're
just focusing on consistency. It's like if you're
trying to be consistent,

you're actually steering away
from the interesting ambiguous stuff that you
might-- that might be a good part of your research.

So there's multiple
valid outcomes, and the success ultimately is
defined by the user's research

questions. Two different people
could have the same data but have different
research questions and have entirely
different codebooks.

So it's a really-- I think it's a good
problem to look at. We did a formative
contextual inquiry study

with five experienced
qualitative coders who did coding of their own data
and then interview afterwards.

They often did have this
hypothesis-driven approach. So we validated that they
that the research question is

determining a great deal of what
their path through the data is, but that the code
book does evolve.

How many folks have done
qualitative coding themselves? So-- At least half of you.

So for that half,
this is redundant. For the half that hasn't
done it, that's for you.

So the themes of interest
to a given participant evolve significantly.

For every step, they're
defining new themes, even though they may be started
with an initial formation

of their intent. By definition,
this is a situation where that initial intent
is going to be wrong.

Right? We have to have
those round trips. Participants wanted it, expected
the AI to improve and expand

their capabilities as long as
they had control and leadership. And they tried to understand
the rationale behind the coding

suggestions because
that was part of what kind of made them decide
whether or not to trust it. And also, what they could learn
from it because ultimately,
the ground truth is in quotes. Right?

A lot of the prior work
on adding AI assistants has been optimized for
accuracy not on user takeaways.

But the ultimate goal
of qualitative coding is not to build a
model of the data

or even to produce the
annotated data set. The goal is to
discover the themes

that you walk away
from that shed light on your research questions.

Again, going back to--
you are a better actor in the world because of this
assistance as opposed to getting the computer to do the thing.

So the primary design goal here
is to optimize our interface for

and our system
design for the user's learning about the
patterns of data. So you can think about this
as a two-dimensional space.

I mean, obviously, this is
a completely made up curve. And maybe there will be a new
technology that just totally is

way off the curve. But for now, like generally,
these lower transparency methods

like deep neural
networks, they are harder to optimize for the
users learning because they are somewhat black box.

Whereas if we give up a
little bit of accuracy, we can gain a great
deal in transparency.

And that is a worthwhile
trade in our argument, if the outcome is not
how good your model is

at taking additional
interview data but rather for you to understand
the answer to your research

question. So with more transparency,
easier for the user to understand and validate
or modify the model directly

or indirectly through
correcting explanations of the model's decision on
an individual piece of data.

So pattern rules are really
promising in this area. So this Cody, not our
work from two CHIs

ago had a code rule engine where
it would take your examples

and come up with an
example of a rule. You could see they're doing some
stemming and some logical over,

but it's a very basic language. And then there because that's
too basic-a-language, it's not--

I'm guessing, it was
not powerful enough in terms of accuracy
to be useful that they augment it with a
black box machine learning

engine. So now, you're getting both
of these recommendations based on the pattern, and also
recommendations separately

from this opaque black box. And so they're trying to have
their cake and eat it too.

It's terrific work. We went a step further. And we have-- we are
synthesizing rules

from examples like
them, but maybe slightly different machinery. But we're using a regular
expression grammar

over parts of speech,
entities, literals, just a particular word,
stems of words, wild cards,

and semantic soft matches,
where something is price-- this is where you
could technically

call it neurosymbolic, which is
all the rage today, where say,

synonyms as identified by
a large language model, but not an opaque
way, not just like--

we have an interface
where you can look at what were
the-- what were matched under the notion of synonym.

By the way, if anyone
has a question, I am very open to being
interrupted, just so you know.

And I also just
want to point out that traditional human in the
loop or interactive machine

learning approaches,
they are often-- I mean, they're not really
built for iteration, they're built for like--

I know what a dog is,
it's very unambiguous. You ask me to create
a classifier for dog? You give me labels?

I predict the rest of the dogs. And that's not the process here. So you could see you know
part of the interface here,

it's built for iteration. You have the ability to
rename, give a different name

for the concept that you're
iterating on merge split or remove these sets of this
multi-classifier system that

is in this case,
what you're seeing. Sorry, I realize
I skipped over-- exactly what the model was. You can see here, this is a
basically a linear combination

or the classifier
output is a linear model

over these high enough
S-score regular expressions

over that grammar
that I described. And you could see over on the
left hand side, for each piece

you document or piece of
data that you would label, the predicted-- if there
is a prediction, the label

and also an explicit--
like what part matched one of the patterns? So you could also
promote a pattern

that was not selected to be used
as part of this linear match. We basically figured that. Again, this balance between
accuracy and transparency,

up to five regular expression
rules with a linear combination of them. We felt like that
was as complex as we

were willing to go to
get accuracy but not lose the ability for
the human to reason

and have an accurate mental
model of what the model is doing on the data. Oh, yes? I have a question.

So for the predicted
price, is that-- so are you essentially adding
the labels of what you think

should be a valid codes for
this and they're finding them? Or are they looking at the
data seeing similarities

and suggesting a code? Right. OK. It's like if this is a mixed
initiative system, who's taking the first initiative?

Or how much initiative
because the computer take? The computer does
not suggest codes.

The conversation-- because
again, thinking of that loop, the humans still has their
own internal research question

that the computer doesn't
know anything about. They will start-- they will
give a couple of examples, and that's what kicks
off the response and then

back and forth. So follow up on that
actually, in that loop, if I just select 10% coupon,
is that enough for it

to generalize? Or how many examples do I
need to give for this thing to kick off roughly? Oh.

Gosh. That's a really great question. I think it's-- I don't know if we start
generating patterns

for a single example. It may be two or three, but
I'll have to check with Simret. But it's a small number?
It's very small. Right. Right. This is few shot learning. Right. Not zero shot but few shot.

And so-- what's
really nice actually

and it's not shown
in the screenshot but it's shown in
like two slides is that once you have these
patterns over the data,

you can reorder these based
on the kind of certainty.

You could group them
by which pattern of the patterns in the model
they satisfy, so you could look

at-- there's various ways you
can leverage those patterns to show people groups. And then also, if
something is marked wrong,

you can look at why
it's marked wrong, and you can annotate
on the piece of code,

not only like is this wrong
and here's the right label. But here's the
part of it that you should be looking at where
one-- where a human would look,

that may be a future
pattern should satisfy, and you can also see when it's
right for the wrong reason,

and then say, yeah. It is about price, but not
because you highlighted the date because of this
word over here instead,

and that will of course
trigger a re-computation of the patterns that best fit
and the linear model over them.

Yes? So like let's say that
there was a person who did not mention price and it
was not about price at all.

Is that going to cause a
problem or are they expecting that pattern to show up in every
single one of the participants

or-- No. Right. So this-- see that
theme drop down?

The thematic
analysis, you're often going to come up with multiple. Yes. Yes. Yes.

So you can choose to work on-- you could create
a new theme, you could switch between
themes you're working on.

Yeah. Well, I'm saying right there
it says predicted not price-- Oh, oh, oh, oh. Yes. When you select one
theme, you're basically

looking at one theme at a time. You could still, I think,
add labels for other themes, but you're looking
at all the data.

It's just-- Does it exist in there or not? Is it-- yeah,
like, price or not, and you could group
them in different ways.

OK. Yeah. Yeah. It's actually
quite-- yeah, it's--

it's a tough system. I think all the
details will not be able to come out
in this talk, but I

hope that you'll look
at the camera ready too. So yeah, so this is-- the user
can understand and validate

or modify the model directly. They can like remove or promote
various regular expressions

to be included forcefully. They can also
indirectly correct just

by annotating
additional examples or correcting what parts of
those examples are the part

that you're telling the
computer to focus on. So if you're looking at
the entire architecture,

you have the user starts
annotating data over there at one. That learns the pattern of users
annotations and synthesizes

rules based over the grammar. It selects a set of rules that
can capture the broadest--

some notion of
coverage and quality. I'm not labeling things
that the person has already explicitly labeled as something
else, and then the user can

group and rank the data on
the left hand side based on these different
possible grouping

modes and ranking methods like
show me the things that it's most confident about or show
me the things it's least confident about.

And then also, these
modifications as you
iterate on the code book. So you can see here-- sorry, like it's very small.

But you can see a
little bit of-- this

is an example of
how you can look at things grouped by similarity
from a BERT standpoint.

You have-- let's say you have a
pattern filter so you can look

at all the sentences
that matched a particular regex
within the model, either one that's
within the model already

or one that's in
the wings waiting to be promoted potentially. So you can-- it's highlighting
the piece that is--

that was the reason that it
matched the pattern in every one of those examples in blue.

So that can make it-- we're just looking at like
are there different ways to even just help
people speed up consuming the recommendations.

And so they can-- also,
as you can see here, they can see when they look at
that blue highlight, the pattern

that it matched. And what that pattern was,
they can tell a system

that wasn't the right pattern. They can split, so
price might actually be two subtly different
categories, like price

and money, and then author two
models out of the original one.

And this is my
favorite because this is the part that
makes it neurosymbolic but is still
intelligible or legible,

because I really hate when
the system is just like and then it magically
does something and I'll never know why. Like this is showing
all the things

in the data that were
considered with respect to the large language
models similar enough.

These are kind of the synonyms. So I know I can go through
and for each one of these if I want for that soft match.

I can say, oh, that is a
misunderstanding of that word or in this context,
that's not a synonym,

even though on
average, it usually is. And I can explicitly say never
match those two in this context.

And so there's just really a
level of control and legibility that I look for in
every one of my systems

that has a neuro
part of the symbolic.

Yes? Yeah. I have a question about
looking at the patterns, I guess from like someone
who's like doing coding.

So if I look at this model
that sees all these weights, how am I supposed
to interpret that? Am I supposed to say
this regular expression

is more important than another? Or is this supposed
to just help me-- That's a great question. Yeah.

I mean, I think strictly
speaking, saying that--

when you have so like 0.9 the
weight on num or or soft match

on expensive for this
notion of price-- so also, it's not clear to me
that these weights are actually
like normalized. I did not read--

like in terms of discussions
with the lead student and our write up, there
was very little discussion of this notion of prior
like focusing more

on one thing versus another. Think of it as like
soft information.

But you can click
on that filter, say, for prop n or
ordinal with a -0.02.

It's like almost like never
factors in and very little bit and like you could click on that
and say what is matching here.

And then you can
debug from there. Maybe it's right to have it.

It's again, this
is like so basic but we're trying to
be expressive enough

to be accurate enough to be
useful while still maintaining legibility, and it's
just this balancing act. I don't think there's
any true right answer.

OK. So let's take a look
at the evaluation. We had eight experienced
qualitative coders come in.

They each spent
two hours with us. They experienced three different
conditions on one of two data sets.

And then we talked
to them afterwards about their experience. In each condition, they
had 100 unique data points

from the same data set. So they were working on the
same data set throughout the two hours but they were
seeing different data

in each condition. It was either restaurant
reviews or hate speech. Now, I think the
hate speech choice,

like we flagged that
in the informed consent was like I think it
was filtered such

I think actually,
there's someone in the room who's done
really great work with one of your new professors on--

the contextual nature of--
that if I remember your work

correctly, so I think
it's an important task, representative task.

So we would give them
a research question to do the qualitative coding. And a counterbalance order, they
experienced a baseline version

of PaTAT without any AI. BERT, so this is
a version of PaTAT

only had the black box model. So there's no explanation
highlights on items or display

of learned patterns. Now, I guess you could have
added some sort of like post hoc analysis. I think, but that is the
choice that we made here.

And then so also a
lot of the strategies that relied on patterns were
no longer available as well

though you could do kind of
BERT level semantic grouping

and then of course with the
full features that I told you. So we asked people to
rank from first to third

and then showed for
the manual condition. It was almost always
first place for ease

of use and perceived user
control, not too surprising. BERT didn't really
win any competition

and then PaTAT was
most frequently ranked first place for
usefulness of facilitating

human learning of data. So given that that last one was
like the design goal number one,

like we can all go home now. But we won't because I'll tell
you a couple other qualitative

insights. So in looking over people's
comments on their experiences,

they felt that
understanding we observed that understanding the
current state of the model did

contribute to error
discovery and repair. So this is maybe less
about person's intent

changing but rather
recognizing that the computer's interpretation of their
intent is incorrect.

So participants found that
user interpretable patterns synthesized for
them to be valuable.

So if it is coding
for good price, I'm looking for a
positive adjective plus a synonym for price
or discounts or whatever.

When I see that it's
on the right track or doing something
like that, it makes me more confident in its
ability to predict, maybe

on data they haven't
looked at yet and its ability
to capture things that I may have missed if
I were the only one going

through the data. So yeah, so these patterns
are interpretable enough

that are qualitative coders
can leverage them in the way that we wanted.

Now, there are some
codes some ideas like atmosphere or
discrimination that

are more challenging to capture
with the grammar over which we are synthesizing patterns.

And so for this, you have
just naturally lower accuracy

of the system. And so in this case, people
are more just instead of looking at the patterns
as the system is trying

to find five regular expressions
over our grammar that would capture atmosphere instead
people looked at the data.

So going through the highlighted
words was kind of the way that they dealt with
that kind of shortcoming

of what I think any system
ultimately would struggle with.

Interpretable patterns also
facilitated the discovery of new themes, trends,
and connections. And this goes back to that
human over on the left hand

side of our loop right where-- yes, they have an initial intent
or an initial idea, expectation.

But in a real system,
especially in thematic analysis but in many other
situations too,

acknowledging and facilitating
the evolution of what they want is really, really critical.

So the patterns also
captured outliers that help people notice
important details and nuance

aspects of the data
